reviewText:
Despite the cutesy artstyle that the game has 'The Binding of Isaac' has to be one of the darkest games I have played in a very long time. The narrative is essentially your struggle as a small naked child, who is trapped in a dungeon, as your mother comes looking for you to kill you. On top of that the game has some very heavy and very dark biblical references.

What really makes 'The Binding of Isaac' a good game though isn't one individual element, its how it all ties together so well to match up thematically bringing together a really compelling experience. The dark overall themes, the random levels with unknown monsters and power up that always keep you on your toes, the music and art design ensuring that you know this is a giant metaphor for a trip through the seven layers of hell. At the end of the day though I know that the 'The Binding of Isaac' isn't for everyone, if you like retro games like Contra then you should get this otherwise stay away because the very reason that makes this game good (a perfect side scrolling shooter true to the genre) is the same reason that people will hate it. Its a matter of taste and you really should be taking some of the blame if you have no idea what you like and don't like by now.

If you want to read a longer review you can find it here on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/07/the-binding-of-isaac.html.

reviewText:
This game is truthfully amazing. I spent some time on it, I wish I could spend some more, and I figured it was worth every digital penny. There are a large amount of items, with the levels changing every time you play, making it never the same game every time you play it.

Pros-

+Soundtracks are amazing
+Difficult, but not impossible
+Large variety of levels
+Large variety of items
+DLC, Wrath of the Lamb adds such a large amount, it's almost like a different game- And in a good way.
+Looks like a classic browser game, and not a hugely computer intensive game
+VERY small download, meaning it should take you less than a good minute (With bad internet) to download
+Not very computer intense

Cons-
-Music volume I found could not be changed, only disabled or enabled
-Satanic references, but if anything has religion references in it there is bound to be something Anti within it

All in all, this game is worth your time and I would suggest it.
So long as you are fine with seeing religion stuff within it.

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a superb rougelike game featureing over 200 items and 50+ monsters the replayablity is endless.

I personally think that if you going to buy this game and you are clueless of what this game is, you should figure it out for yourself rather than watching a Let's play or any sort of walktrough of it.

And why you may ask?

Because one of the biggest strong points about this game is learning what everything does and what should bosses and enemies you should be thirlled from.

Altrough this game is pretty modern game it is more based on retro games and the diffuclty curve is alot bigger then other exsisting game which adds to the fun of this game

Over the top you have the awesome looking artstyle and the amazingly fitting religious soundtrack made by Danny B. which made also the soundtrack for another one of Edmund Mcmillen games Super Meat Boy

I find that the weakset point of this game is the fact it runs on flash and it means it very limited by performance and on rooms with alot of enemies and particle effects the game may run poorly even on high-end machines.

I think that in this 5$ price point, and it is a must have for any type of gamer.

Not convinced yet?
Go to Newgrounds and try the demo for yourself!

reviewText: The Binding of Isaac is an addictive twin-stick shooter that rejuvenated the roguelike genre and gifts players with a memorable gaming experience, though it is thoroughly hampered by technical flaws, creative limitations and the existence of a wholly-superior successor.\n\nIn Isaac, you play as the titular character, a five-year-old boy, fleeing from his homicidal mother throughout the realms that exist beneath his basement. Isaac uses his tears as bullets to fire at enemies. He's aided by items, trinkets, pills and cards that he finds along the way, which further disfigure him until he is almost unrecognizable by the end of the game. The full game can be beat on average in under an hour - this is the staple element of the roguelike" genre

column20: underscoring Isaac's desperation throughout his journey. Overarching visual presentation possesses an air of artistry

column31: by getting every item available or forcing the game to crash while trying to get there. What is arguably more dissappointing than these technical issues are the ample lack of synergies. Though some basic tear modifiers can stack on in large numbers to create crazy effects

column34: Isaac was still the standard-bearer for the roguelike genre and was a phenominally popular game. However

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac Game Review

The binding of Isaac is a indie rogue-like platformer game about a child called Isaac and his crazy religious mother. It is a game filled with secrets and unlockable characters and items with 2 DLC packs. After playing The Binding of Isaac for a few hours I realised there was a reason so many people described the game as â€œUnforgivingâ€ and â€œdisturbingâ€, Itâ€™s because its filled with satanic references, blood and gore. Not only that but The Binding of Isaac is incredibly difficult, only after my first 10 tries was I able to kill mom once. My favourite thing about The Binding of Isaac would have to be the game breaking aspect. By game breaking I mean there are some incompatible items in the game which cause you to have infinite health or can help you to get every item in the game. There is actually a massive part of the community that has dedicated itself to finding game breaking glitches that can make them extremely overpowered; some of these people have broken the game to the extent that a single attack on any boss will kill them instantly.

Controls and Gameplay

The controls to The Binding of Isaac are basic. WASD to move and your arrow keys to direct your attack. You move around the basement from room to room, each room containing something different. There are normal rooms which contain enemies, gold rooms which contain power up items that will impact your speed, damage, health and can sometimes impact you negatively.
You first meet Isaac and his mother in the loading screen for the game which describes their lives as being happy until she hears a voice from above. The voice of god tells her to kill Isaac and Isaac, hearing this, flees into the houses basement to get away from his homicidal mother which is when the games main menu loads.  The game is about Isaac making his way through the basement to eventually reach and kill the boss, Mom. As you make your way through the basement you will encounter multiple different types of enemies (foetuses, pinworms, embryos, flaming headless monsters and lots of bugs) which will all try to kill you.

Graphics and Sound

The graphics for The Binding of Isaac were made to have a retro feel to them. They have options for the in game detail which affects the rooms you enter. High detail means there will be cobwebs and blood on the walls while low detail will give you none of that. The detail setting also affects the pixels in game so setting it to low will give you a very fuzzy effect while high makes it look HD in comparison.
The music in The Binding of Isaac is very varied. The music changes depending on the floor and room you are on/in. The music keeps you focused while playing and can help you to know what type of room or floor you are on.  The sounds in The Binding of Isaac are very eerie to say the least. The squishing noises when you kill monsters and the screaming from bosses I found to be very unsettling when I was playing and actually impacted on my performance when I was playing.

Replayability and Multiplayer

The Binding of Isaac is literally the most replayable game I have ever played; this is because of how unforgiving the game and how interesting the storyline is. With over 341 items and 178 secrets in the game you must replay constantly to finish the game with everything unlocked.
There has never been a official multiplayer feature for The Binding of Isaac however the great community surrounding it has created a few multiplayer mods for people to use. This let you play 2 players with you and another person on the same keyboard and you can both move around and shoot and fight enemies. Although the multiplayer mod is good, I think it ruins the game as there is no balancing aspect to the mod meaning there is now2 players but the same amount of bosses and enemies.

To Conclude

I found The Binding of Isaac to be a ridiculously good indie game. The complexity of the story line and the references to religion surprised me and definitely made me enjoy the game a lot more. At only Â£4.00 this game is definitely one I would pick up off the steam store, especially as it is now one of my most played games and itâ€™s one of the cheapest I own, this game practically pays for itself in minutes. The games DLC is also worth getting as it doubles the amount of content that is already inside this jam packed game, it adds characters, items, floors, monsters and more difficult bosses.  So to give this game a rating I would have to give it a:
â€¢	Easy to learn controls âœ“
â€¢	Gameplay âœ“
â€¢	Graphics âœ“
â€¢	Sound/Music âœ“
â€¢	Replayable âœ“
â€¢	Multiplayer  X
RATED 5/6

reviewText: This game is a complete surprise.  The graphics are minimalistic, the sounds are average, and the gameplay quite retro zelda like.  But for some reason, because it's a short game that can only take you 30 minutes to beat in one playthrough it's not about the one playthrough.  Each time through you will find different random upgrades or weapons, different monsters, different bosses and of course different loot.  This is by no means an easy game.  Might get frustrating, but for some reason I keep coming back to it.  This game is fun!

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac Game Review

The binding of Isaac is a indie rogue-like platformer game about a child called Isaac and his crazy religious mother. It is a game filled with secrets and unlockable characters and items with 2 DLC packs. After playing The Binding of Isaac for a few hours I realised there was a reason so many people described the game as â€œUnforgivingâ€ and â€œdisturbingâ€, Itâ€™s because its filled with satanic references, blood and gore. Not only that but The Binding of Isaac is incredibly difficult, only after my first 10 tries was I able to kill mom once. My favourite thing about The Binding of Isaac would have to be the game breaking aspect. By game breaking I mean there are some incompatible items in the game which cause you to have infinite health or can help you to get every item in the game. There is actually a massive part of the community that has dedicated itself to finding game breaking glitches that can make them extremely overpowered; some of these people have broken the game to the extent that a single attack on any boss will kill them instantly.

Controls and Gameplay

The controls to The Binding of Isaac are basic. WASD to move and your arrow keys to direct your attack. You move around the basement from room to room, each room containing something different. There are normal rooms which contain enemies, gold rooms which contain power up items that will impact your speed, damage, health and can sometimes impact you negatively.
You first meet Isaac and his mother in the loading screen for the game which describes their lives as being happy until she hears a voice from above. The voice of god tells her to kill Isaac and Isaac, hearing this, flees into the houses basement to get away from his homicidal mother which is when the games main menu loads.  The game is about Isaac making his way through the basement to eventually reach and kill the boss, Mom. As you make your way through the basement you will encounter multiple different types of enemies (foetuses, pinworms, embryos, flaming headless monsters and lots of bugs) which will all try to kill you.

Graphics and Sound

The graphics for The Binding of Isaac were made to have a retro feel to them. They have options for the in game detail which affects the rooms you enter. High detail means there will be cobwebs and blood on the walls while low detail will give you none of that. The detail setting also affects the pixels in game so setting it to low will give you a very fuzzy effect while high makes it look HD in comparison.
The music in The Binding of Isaac is very varied. The music changes depending on the floor and room you are on/in. The music keeps you focused while playing and can help you to know what type of room or floor you are on.  The sounds in The Binding of Isaac are very eerie to say the least. The squishing noises when you kill monsters and the screaming from bosses I found to be very unsettling when I was playing and actually impacted on my performance when I was playing.

Replayability and Multiplayer

The Binding of Isaac is literally the most replayable game I have ever played; this is because of how unforgiving the game and how interesting the storyline is. With over 341 items and 178 secrets in the game you must replay constantly to finish the game with everything unlocked.
There has never been a official multiplayer feature for The Binding of Isaac however the great community surrounding it has created a few multiplayer mods for people to use. This let you play 2 players with you and another person on the same keyboard and you can both move around and shoot and fight enemies. Although the multiplayer mod is good, I think it ruins the game as there is no balancing aspect to the mod meaning there is now2 players but the same amount of bosses and enemies.

To Conclude

I found The Binding of Isaac to be a ridiculously good indie game. The complexity of the story line and the references to religion surprised me and definitely made me enjoy the game a lot more. At only Â£4.00 this game is definitely one I would pick up off the steam store, especially as it is now one of my most played games and itâ€™s one of the cheapest I own, this game practically pays for itself in minutes. The games DLC is also worth getting as it doubles the amount of content that is already inside this jam packed game, it adds characters, items, floors, monsters and more difficult bosses.  So to give this game a rating I would have to give it a:
â€¢	Easy to learn controls âœ“
â€¢	Gameplay âœ“
â€¢	Graphics âœ“
â€¢	Sound/Music âœ“
â€¢	Replayable âœ“
â€¢	Multiplayer  X
RATED 5/6

The Binding of Isaac is a game for people with sick sense of humor and patience. Defeat 7 sins, make deals with the devil, kill your own mother.
Personally I don't like roguelike games but this one is totally different. I clearly understand why it's so popular.

Game has one flaw: poor optimalization, even on Intel Quad core, GTX760 there are moments when it starts  to work very sloooooow.

reviewText:
The binding of Isaac
Plot: One day Isaac's moms got an whisper from GOD!?" he asked to sacrifice her son in the name of faith. You need to play the game for find why? or how? god want
Isaac life.
Gameplay: WASD for move and arrow keys for shot projectile tears Q for use cards/pills and space bar for use activated item.
Pros
- Have a dozens of useful items.
- Have a hundred of unlockables.
- Every floor alway randoms
- Randomized items every time you start the game.
Cons
- Really need some luck for play.
- Sometime the game will not tell you how item you found work(You need to find how to use by youself).
- It doesn't offer 360-controller support.
- Alway keep you guessing.
If you like dark theme adventure and very brutal games you will enjoy this game.
Also try DLC Wrath Of The Lamb for more epicness."

reviewText: Umm... I don't know what to say about this game. it's... Weird. But overall (Even though i played a little on this account, and about 250+ hours on my old account), it's a fantastic, evenly priced game. Gives a Lot of Hours of Gameplay (Reaching the Cathedral is HARD, and takes over 13 successful runs that take a crapton of time >.<), with Many (MANY!) Items that appear randomly through the many levels (Random as well, for Pretty much Endless Fun), And will make you Become pretty much a Tank to anything that comes after You. A thing that's also Impressive is that how The game itself has a Kind of Creepy and Morbid Gameplay, but also Really Fun and Bizzarre, and Still Holding up to Comic-Like Graphics. More things like Challenges, Character selection (Each with its own Special Item and Starting Stats), A Handful of different Enemies, Random Bosses Each Level, Collection of Items, A lot of In-Game and Steam Achievements (With Many In-Game Unlockables to be found), An Interesting Backstory of the Main Character And a Fantastic amount of 13+ Endings, Make the Icing on this Strange But Amazing Cake. Also, You can Tear" Down Enemies. *Da Bum Tss*. Overall

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a bit of an oddity for me to review. First let me explain the game. You play a character who shoots enemies in his basement with his tears. The levels consist of several interconnected rooms, through which you generally fight a group of gruesome bad guys (zombies, mutant spiders, etc.). You fight through enough of them to get keys or coins, which allow you to open up rooms with upgrades or to buy upgrades. Each floor has a boss fight, after which you'll drop down to the next floor, then repeat the process.

Now let me talk about the difficulty. You will quickly find this game does not mess around. You start off with three hearts. Each hit takes away half a heart; six hits and you're dead. If you die, you go back to the beginning of the game (absolutely no saves). On top of that, you often face multiple enemies who can move faster than you and can shoot projectiles. You also have extremely little recovery time with each hit. You'll need to explore every room to hopefully find powerups or money so you can pay for a little bit of health. Don't expect to find much health throughout each stage, except after bosses. This is easily one of the most difficult games that I've actually still managed to have fun with. Yes, it is frustrating at times, but it never seems unfair. The game plays by a certain set of rules and will always abide by them. There's a certain amount of comfort in knowing that. The enemies on the other hand, they range from mildly annoying to downright evil. But you'll see that for yourself if you buy this game.

The game's aesthetic design is great, the music is great, and the story, while macabre, is pretty interesting. The control is very good and the game is consistent in its dark atmosphere that some would call over-the-top dark humor. The art and level design are, for the most part, pretty simple, but that's okay. The game comes off as cartoony, but I think that contributes to the over-the-top gothic feel. Artistically speaking, it kinds of runs in a similar vein as Salad Fingers.

While the Binding of Isaac is repetitive, there's actually a lot of variety. The game mixes up the bosses, each room is randomly generated with random enemies and random items, and there are a TON of different powerups. While it should feel like you're going through the motions again and again, for some reason it doesn't. The story isn't anything deep, of course, and any semblance of an actual plot is non-existent. You play through a floor, then drop down to the next; wash, rinse, and repeat. It's very similar to Diablo in that fashion. Some people may like that and that's fine, but just know that that's what this game is. While this seemingly meaningless trek initially irked me, I've gotten used to it and now I see the game for what it is. It's not really trying to be something it's not, and as far as original arcade shooters go, this one is probably the best I've ever played. The no-save feature is necessary, I now feel, because it encourages retrying and retrying. It builds skill. The random nature of the game is definitely a plus because you never play through the game with the exact map and enemy placement twice. The game's large amount of variety ensures the game has high replay value.

I've gone back and forth on my opinions with this game. Originally I had mixed feelings because some of the less conventional aspects didn't jibe with my personal preference. However, it is strangely addicting and fun. The difficulty spikes at the fifth floor and gets to (in my opinion) near-impossible levels without mastery. At the moment, the price point ($4.99 for the base game, $2.99 for the DLC) is very good. It's a fun time-waster, especially if you've got a dark sense of humor. Even though I'm not really a fan of arcade shooters, this one sucked me in, and I can't really explain it. As I said before, the art design, music, and controls are all very good, and while the game gets incredibly difficult, it always seems fair. Most importantly, The Binding of Isaac doesn't claim to be something it's not, so it's important to see it for what it is. I've gone back on my mixed feelings and now say that I do recommend this one if you have a dark sense of humor and/or enjoy difficult games.

reviewText:
I told myself I wasn't going to write a review until I beat the game. But after playing 3 hours of this brutal top down dungeon crawler I realized I may never write a review. With that being said, lets get right into it.

The Binding of Isaac is a top down dungeon crawler game based off of a story in the Bible. The story goes is that there is a a man named Abraham who is visted by God himself and is asked to sacrafice his son Isaac. This story is a lot like The Binding of Isaac (Discount the monsters and dungeons).

Right off the bat you can see that The Binding of Isaac is not just some regular top down dungeon crawler game. It has amazing art combined with a dark depressing theme. Each and every enemy you encounter will shock you, you will have to remember these enemies, how they look like, and their attack patterns in order to advance further into the game. The items are goofy and loveable. Now lets do some pros and cons.

Pros:
- Fantasic soundtrack that will always keep you pumped up for the next boss
- Vague yet incapturing story
- A large variety of enemies that will only get harder as you avance further into the game
- Unlockable characters, somthing to always strive to
- There are indeed multiple endings
- Until you've seen all endings and unlocked all characters and collected all items, there is always replay value

Cons:
- This game is impossibly difficult

I know there is only one con but that con is no joke. This game is hard and unforgiving. It's fun at times but it really does suck when you die right before the Mom Fight". It has a deep learning curve and there is no description on any item you get
date: which means in order to use it right you have to look it up on the wikia. If you intend on buying this game there is a few things to know.\n\n1) You are buying a game that is difficult
recommended: and there's no way of changing that.\n\n2)  If you plan on really going hard at this game
hoursPlayed: there is some reseach and memorizing involed.\n\n3) If you are religious in any way
voteText: you may find this game's content to be offensive.\n\nMy final thought on this game is that it's a well made indie cult classic. I enjoy this game enough to play it every once and a while but not crazy about it. As for the DLC and Rebirth
helpfulPercent: I do not plan on buying those anytime soon.\n\n8.5/10"

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a fun and addictive flash game well worth the price you're paying for it.
I have already put more hours in this simple little flash of 5 euros full priced than in a ''Next-gen revolutionary'' game.
The gameplay is easy to learn and understand and the later levels are always challenging.
But all good things must have a bad side.
Once you get an fair amount of items the game starts dropping in framerate which can be a bit frustrating.
Also the game can get really easy or really difficult depending on certain item drops.
Such as the ''Mom's knife'' and ''Sacred Heart'' combo which basicly allows you to 1-shot almost all enemies in the game (Including bosses).
Otherwise it is possible to receive only activateable items which you can only carry 1 of at a time, resulting in getting no proper stats making the game near-impossible to complete.

All things set aside I think it's a great game which is fun to play or watch others play.
The price can drop below 2 euros during steam sales so if you need a fun game that's easy to pick up, look no further!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: First of all this game has a style and it is something more than just a dungeon & loot game, It has a spirit.When i started playing, the soundtacks and isaac's story impressed me, but it was really hard to play and i could barely survive 1 or 2 floors. As i played and started learning new things about the game (i am still learning in spite of my playtime) it has just became more and more enjoying because there are tons of monsters, items, achievements (most of the achievements unlock an item so it has a chance to drop when you unlock the achievement), and bosses in the game. When you die, you start from the begining, but it never bothered me because everything is completely random. Everytime you play, every single monster, every room, every boss, every item you get and even the alignment of rooms are different! The facts like there are 2 secret rooms every floor, or pills giving you random effects, or the devil and angel rooms makes the game even more exciting . Besides it is replayable-duh- when you finish the game for the first time it adds two more levels (floors) and more bosses to the game and when you finish the game like 11th time it unlocks 3 more levels (one of them is optional). The downside is, it sometimes really stimulates me to lose all those gear I collected because of a momentary mistake but I am really glad I bought the game. It is a ''must have'' in my opinion. If you haven't bought the game yet, I highly recommend you to buy it.

reviewText:
Edmund Mcmillian, you did another successful job of making another indie game. Binding of Isaac is an adventure and a lot of relegious things including the title. The story gets better and makes more sensesince the beginning isnt enough. The story is about you (Isaac) and your mother just chillin until your mother thinks God is talking to her and tells her to get rid of everything in your life since they are sins of his life. So she obeyed 'God' and took everything in Isaac's life (including his cloths and your naked the whole game). 'God' now tells her to go KILL Isaac if she truly loves 'God' more than Isaac. Well guess what she literally grabbed a knife and attempted to barge in his room. Luckly, Isaac finds a basement door in his room and your adventure starts.
As you go through the basement, you encounter enemies which you kill them by SHOOTING YOUR OWN TEARS (total logic).
You also find items which most of them help you by increasing speed, length of tears and damage. and give you wings.
There are special rooms like stores, death chambers and challenge rooms this is how you get to those 3 rooms:

Store: open it with a key or if theres a secret room beside it, just cheat and blow up the wall beside the store.
Death Chamber: a room with only spikes, if your stupid enough (joke) to go to the spike and attempt to kill yourself, you actually can make a chest appear.
Challenge room: if you beat the room beside the challenge room without taking damage, you can get in.

Health in this game is hard to get since you start with 3 hearts and finding them wont be easy. Now let's see how long you can survive under your house besides being a 2-floor basement.
I give this game 9 out of 10 due to the difficulity and the most shocking thing about the game is that theres 7 characters (all mentioned in the bible) and you gotta beat the entire game 32 TIMES IN TOTAL. So have fun i know you can do it (not).

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike game in which you play as a child traversing through randomly generated levels with the goal of stopping your mom from killing you. There is a large number of items that also randomly generate each playthrough that you can use to aid in your adventure. As you play the game, you unlock secrets and additional items to use in future playthroughs.

With the Wrath of Lamb DLC, there are additional items, a new item type, floors (as opposed to levels), and bosses. The DLC also introduces challenges that limit (or otherwise challenge) you, which upon completion unlock new items for the main game. If you are considering buying The Binding of Isaac, I highly recommend also purchasing the Wrath of Lamb DLC.

This game is heavy on both skill and luck. You will die a lot when you start playing the game. It will take many, many attempts to defeat the first final boss for the first time. As you complete playthroughs and unlock secrets, you will gain skill and new items that may help you in future playthroughs.

The biggest issue with this game is that the framerate drops when a lot of tears (projectiles) or flashing enemies (flies), probably due to using the Flash engine. This is highly noticeable while playing the game, especially upon completing two certain bosses. It took me at least 10 in-game hours to get used to the wild framerate. Another issue is that the game may almost crash when it tries generating certain floors, which can be resolved by waiting for the program to respond even if the option to close the problem comes up.

If you are interested in trying out the game, it is fairly cheap normally ($4.99 + $2.99 DLC ( $6.60 bundle)). If you wait for it as a specific Steam Sale, the combined cost is aroudn $0.68, which is definitely worth the purchase.

That said, if you are interested in the game and would probably play this game a lot (tens and tens of hours), I would recommend purchasing The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, which is a remake of the original game and DLC. A lot of new items, challenges, characters, enemies, and bosses are introduced. The art style is better (imo), the mechanics are better due to the change in game engine, and the game runs much more smoothly. The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth costs $14.99 normally. It is up to you on which you purchase if you want to.

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a frustratingly-fun and challenging zelda-style rogue-lite, created by Edmund McMillen (Super Meat Boy) and Florian Himsl (Coil, The C-Word).

The game features a ton of variables in the forms of characters, bosses, items, and power-ups, all of which can alter how much you progress throughout the game.

With hilarious (and sometimes creepy) references to faith, religion, human ethics, and biology, Isaac is a delicious slice of blasphemy, served with a sour lemon.

reviewText: I puchased this game during the winter steam sale of 2013 as my first game and it is addicting. It has a oldschool top down dungeon crawler like feel, very much to the dungeons of old school legend of zelda on the NES. The graphics are in 2-D, 16-bit , and the fact that the visuals looks like it was drawn by a 5th grade, brings a unique blend of cute,grotesque, perhaps morbid feel to the aesthetics of this humorus and twisted game. This game was devloped by the geniuses behind Super Meat boy. The gameplay is simple moving with AWSD and shooting tears with the arrow button and droping bombs. The random generated dungeons, powerups,and the hardcore difficulty are some of the mechanics that makes the game shine. The comvination of these mechanics of gameplay is also what can be its weakness to some people. There over 100 difrent items and powerups within the game and sometimes these can make or break your dungeon run. While playing this game you may have moments between woot this is awsome" and "dman.. this sucks alil" when it comes to what you find
date: but dont let that slow you down it's uncommon for the later but it dose happen.  It's a hillarious
recommended: brutal and fun game to play. If you happen to see this game on sale it's a must have!"

reviewText: Binding of Isaac is a shooter game with heavy inspiration from The Legend of Zelda and various roguelikes. It features permanant death, so you have to stay focused while playing. You must dodge monsters and destroy them with your tears, collecting randomly dropped items scattered around the randomly generated dungeons. I've made it to the final boss, but have yet to beat it, and likely will not because I am waiting for the remake of Binding of Isaac to come out before I spend more time playing it. You could easily compare this to Teleglitch, but that game is a lot less random in terms of the items you find and enemies you encounter (even the boss progression is somewhat random in Binding of Isaac).\n\nStill, if you like what you see in videos on Youtube, etc... you can't go wrong for the price, and I do recommend this version until the remake is available.

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone. It's tough as nails and very dependant on luck. If you like roguelikes, exploration, and finding great combos, this is the game for you. Don't touch it if you prefer more casual experiences, if dying bothers you or if you don't like starting for the beginning on each run, without saves.

Once you put that aside, it has a very deep meaning hidden behind those cartoonish graphics. The game will keep you on your toes, making you wonder what's next and how to overcome them. Even in adversity, a little of good luck can turn the tide of the battle, and making poor decisions is punishing.

However, as you play, you'll develop new strategies, and find combinations and combinations of items that are going to help you survive the horrid world that is the basement. You'll get beams, lasers, chocolate and more to fight your enemies, which get increasingly hard. Even with bad luck, good reflexes and strategy will make you survive each run.

reviewText:
Having just gotten 100% on this game, I think it's time that I give my review.

To put it simply, this is my favorite game. Period.

Since everything in the game is quite literally random (room layout, floor layout, power-ups, items, enemies, bosses etc.) it provides an immense level of replayability. I have put 270 hours into this game and have had to start from scratch due to a corrupted save and still I absolutely love it and play it nearly every day.

I always love a high level of challenge and difficulty and The Binding of Isaac provides this in SPADES.

At $8 for the game and the DLC (which is essential, in my opinion) this game is a great value. Better yet, it is often on sale for a couple dollars and this makes it a MUST BUY if you also enjoy a challenging and highly replayable game.

reviewText:
If Charles Manson played this game, he would definitely give it a 10/10

What twisted minds did the developers of The Binding of Isaac have. How disturbing is a mother trying to kill her son who escaped to the basement, and can kill anything with his tears.

Exploring the basement, you come across all sorts of horrendous monsters, decapitated catsâ€™ heads, piles of faeces lying around and of course, your motherâ€™s pads...among many other disturbing things.

However once you become desensitized, this little game is pretty good. Going through each level, finding power-ups (or power-downs) to help you with the increasingly difficult monsters, ultimately fighting a boss to proceed to the next level of the basement.

There is no continuity, so once you die, you start again from the beginning. Everything is randomly generated, so you will never have the same experience twice.

Itâ€™s a really fun and interesting game, with alot of little references to other games -  You might find a pixelated pickaxe as a power-up, which of course, is Notch's pickaxe. You might come across a monster that spews toxic green acid, just like the one from Left for Dead 2 - and the list goes on.

For the price you should certainly try this game out.

My rating - 8/10

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone. It's tough as nails and very dependant on luck. If you like roguelikes, exploration, and finding great combos, this is the game for you. Don't touch it if you prefer more casual experiences, if dying bothers you or if you don't like starting for the beginning on each run, without saves.

Once you put that aside, it has a very deep meaning hidden behind those cartoonish graphics. The game will keep you on your toes, making you wonder what's next and how to overcome them. Even in adversity, a little of good luck can turn the tide of the battle, and making poor decisions is punishing.

However, as you play, you'll develop new strategies, and find combinations and combinations of items that are going to help you survive the horrid world that is the basement. You'll get beams, lasers, chocolate and more to fight your enemies, which get increasingly hard. Even with bad luck, good reflexes and strategy will make you survive each run.

reviewText:
This game... Oh goodness, this game.

The basis for this game originates around a small story in the bible, where Abraham is told to kill his son, as an act of obedience; His son's name, of course is Isaac. Upon almost achieving this goal, an angel stops him, letting him know it was merely a test. It is known as one of the most controversial bits of the bible, so I assume that's what sparked the creator's desire to make this game.

reviewText:
The name Isaac is derived from a Hebrew word that means '' He laughs '' which is ironic since the character that you play kills his enemies with his own tears. If that isn't unsettling enough, the game itself is inspired by the biblical story of the binding of Isaac, where a father (Abraham) is commanded by God to sacrifice his son, Isaac. (In this case, Isaac's mother hears God who commands her to kill him to purge him of all his sins, yikes).

Please, do not shy away from this game from all the religious undertones and various symbolisms scattered throughout it, because The Binding of Isaac is so much more than that.

After playing it for 230 hours, I was finally able to 100% the game. Some players might take more time to achieve this and some less. And I can strongly say, this is a very well constructed and very addictive game that offers much replayability and challenges, especially for such a low price (DLC a must!).

It's a rogue-like ''zelda-esque'' game with randomly generated floors, rooms, items, enemy fights and bosses. It's the type of game that, indeed, has to do with luck but also skill. While everything is somehow random, by learning what items do and how to fully take advantage of all the tools and mechanics the game offers, you will eventually become comfortable adventuring floors with each playthrough.

The game will be frustrating and very hard, but when you finally get your first win, it's oh so satisfiying ^w^b and it can only get better from there hehehe...

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is similar in a number of ways (difficulty, room layout, enemy types) to the original Legend of Zelda for the NES. The main difference being of course that this game is top-down shooter with largely random item/power-up drops, which changes gameplay considerably. I HEARTILY recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a serious challenge, wants massive replay value, and is not going to be driven away by the rogue-like elements and the clever, but unsettling art direction. I've laid out the most pertinent pros and cons below to give a better understanding of whether you'll want to play this game.

Pros:
Huge replay value (randomization, a number of unique playable characters, additional levels unlocked after beating the game)
Great level and enemy design (despite being somewhat derivative of the original Zelda)
Medium/High difficulty level (you have to work for it)
Brilliant and meaningful achievement system (every achievement unlocks a new item to be obtained in-game)

Cons:
Occasional fps slowdown when a number of enemies are onscreen (can be fixed by reducing quality settings)
Freezes occasionally when loading later levels (simply needs time to fix itself)
There are a number of bugs related to ahievement unlocks in Steam, but seems have almost everything right in-game (playthroughs with one character count as wins with another, for example)
Art style makes frequent references to abuse and other somewhat taboo themes and can be very unsettling at first
The sheer number of items available can force a decision between on-the-fly play (with weird item interactions) and having the wiki open in the background to understand your items

reviewText: From the makers of Super Meat Boy comes this great, terryifyingly bizarre game. This game mixes overhead third person shooting with the dungeon exploration of the original Legend of Zelda. The is is a roguelike, meaning it has RPG like stats, randomly generated levels, and if you die you have to start all over. Various enemies require strategy and skill, and the bosses have the game feeling like a SHUMP bullet hell game at times. There are TONS of items and skills, that boost stats, changes your ammo, or giving you unique skills like shooting through walls. The game varies difficulty, sometimes being a walk in the park or frustratingly difficult, but it's pick up and play style mixed with the short game time and endless replayability make this a great game at a very cheap price.

reviewText: The Bnding of Issac is a (like most people all it) a Zelda-like dungeon crawler. Yep, damn straight that's what it is. While this game is awesome, there are a few things that I have issues with. Let's start with the good things, shall we? Okay, the art style is awesome! I love the cartoony yet dark feel this game has to it. While it is a game that is dead serious, it's pretty funny with all of it's power-ups (which there are a frigging ton of) and bosses. Oh and good GOD ALMIGHTY that soundtrack. The music is creepy and also very catchy. PLUS! Every dungeon/ basement or whattheâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ ever is random EVERY TIME, making every playthrough different. The characters and story are cool and funny (and down-right terrifying sometimes) and the enemies are also creepy and sometimes cute-ish. Now, those 'bad things' I said earlier? They really don't matter; but here we go. First, it's a flash game; therefore, it runs like â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ (for me. I have an awfull computer). The lag, yes, can really pull me from the game, but it's something I get used to. And finally is that a lot of the power-ups are kindda crappy. But all-in-all, it's a great game, and I can easily recomend everyone to it.     Final Score=8.75/10\n\nEdit: I got Windows 8.1 and somehow my game runs like 50% better. Final FINAL Score =9.75/10

reviewText:
I passed up on this game a while ago because I wasn't entirely sure about it. Just a while ago, I purchased the game for $5 on Steam and started playing it. This game is extremely fun. There is no reason for anyone who likes games to not get this game. The game costs $5 and I've already played it longer than some $20-$40 games.

STORY:
You play as Isaac, a small child who has been thrown into the basement under his house after his mother supposedly heard a message from god telling her to sacrifice her son. You, as Isaac, must traverse the basement, going deeper and deeper in an effort to survive the horrors in the depths below.

GAMEPLAY:
The game takes place from a Birds-eye viewpoint, and you control Isaac using WASD and his tear shots using the arrow keys or the mouse. His tears can shoot in 4 cardinal directions (NSEW) and are used as Isaacs primary attack. On your way, there are secret rooms to find coins, shops to purchase items, treasure rooms to get new abilities, boss rooms to fight bosses, devil rooms to give up some hearts for a rare and special item, and so forth. The game has enough variety to keep me coming back for more and trying to perfect my run".

GRAPHICS:
The game uses a sort-of cutesy vector graphics format
date: which works well in contrast of the dark undertones of the game. Elements and enemies that need to stand out do so
recommended: while things that aren't as important don't attract your eyes attention
hoursPlayed:
something very important in games similar to The Binding of Isaac.

BALANCE:
The Binding of Isaac is well balanced
voteText: but it is easier to talk about what is not balanced rather than talk about what is. Tears Upgrades tend to be rather useless
helpfulPercent: as they are outshadowed in usefullness by their bigger brother "The Damage Upgrade"
votesHelpful: and the knockback produced from tears can go out of control with enough tears upgrades
votesTotal: sending enemies flying in all directions and making it harder to dodge. The game is also based on luck quite a bit
votesFunny: from the upgrades you draw to the rooms that you find
commentsCount: but it also requires a lot of skill
column16: something you earn from playing the game. Additionally
column17: some of the upgrades just plain suck. Other than that
column18:
the game is well balanced.

OVERVIEW:
The Binding of Isaac is a Birds-Eye dungeon crawler with a fantastic concept and huge buckets of replayability. This game would be high up on my Top 10 Favorite Games list if I had one."

reviewText:
This game teaches you to wash your hands before food.

Indeed, if you pay attention - you'll see that all your enemies are, in fact, hallucinations of your vivid unstable child's mind. They are grotesque versions of himself, trying to bully him.

The reason for all this is quite simple: your hero (Isaac) doesn't like wearing clothes and touches a lot of dirty things: spoons, shoes, hourglass (very dirty), mom's panties, etc.

Germs are transmitted very easily, and since you play as a child with a weak immune system, it's very likely that you've caught something because of your careless behaviour.


You deserve to die.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games of all time!

The binding of Isaac is a rough like game, where you have to go through a sereis of rooms, in order to omplete a level.

The game is acually difficult, amnd at times, you will have geat challanges to overcome, like bosses or big pulls of enemyes.

The story is simple, you are playing as Isaac (or some of the charectes you can unlock) and has to escape Mom, becouse she is trying to kill you in gods name. The story is not really anything that matters for a game like this, but it is nice to know why Isaac is running around in a creappy basement, full of monsters.

The controles are simple, you can move in any direction, and you can shot in four directions, up, down, left and right. Along the way you will find upgrades, that can make you shot in other directions, shot faster, do more damage, gain more life, get friends to shot together with you and many more items.

The funny part about the items, is that they don`t tell you, what the item can do. You either have to look at your stats, or try to shot, in order to see what the item did for you. If nothing changes, it can get really diffecult to find out what the item did, and you have to remember what meny items did, so you don`t end up downgrading youself.

There are also tarot cards, that do diffrent things like clearing rooms, make enemyes take damage, teleport ypu and many more things.

There are diffrent roomes on the map, that do diffrent things.

The plain rooms, are just a figting room, you have to kill all the enemeyes in a room, in order to countinue to a nother room.

There is a sacrifice room, where you have to take damage, in order to get an item.

There is the a shop, where you can buy items for coins, this can be health, weapons, tarot cards, nearly everything.

Then there is a secret room, where you have to bomb away a wall, in order to get in. If you don`t have a map that shows you where this room is, you have to bomb random walls.

There is an arcade, where you can gamble, with your money and win prices.

Then there is a tressure room, where you unlock the door with a key, in order to get an item.

And then there is the boss rooms, and this is where the real action happens. To advance in the game, you have to defeat a boss, and the bosses are random selected, based on whitch floor you are on. The bosses can be hard, and some can be easy, but I would say they all are very injoable.

So about the diffeculty, it is not only due to hard mobs and bosses, but also becouse it is a rough like game, if you die, you die, no countinues. This can get you very frusterated at times, but it is also the charm of a rough like game. You will end up dying a lot, and if you don`t have the right items, or haven`t found anything speceail, the game will punish you for that.

The game has fantastic music! I love evety single track, and I promiss you will too! The music are very atmosferic, and they are good to psyck you up.

This is one of my favorite games, it is fun, addicting and overall a fantastc game, thumps up. 8 out of 10

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike game in which you play as a child traversing through randomly generated levels with the goal of stopping your mom from killing you. There is a large number of items that also randomly generate each playthrough that you can use to aid in your adventure. As you play the game, you unlock secrets and additional items to use in future playthroughs.

With the Wrath of Lamb DLC, there are additional items, a new item type, floors (as opposed to levels), and bosses. The DLC also introduces challenges that limit (or otherwise challenge) you, which upon completion unlock new items for the main game. If you are considering buying The Binding of Isaac, I highly recommend also purchasing the Wrath of Lamb DLC.

This game is heavy on both skill and luck. You will die a lot when you start playing the game. It will take many, many attempts to defeat the first final boss for the first time. As you complete playthroughs and unlock secrets, you will gain skill and new items that may help you in future playthroughs.

The biggest issue with this game is that the framerate drops when a lot of tears (projectiles) or flashing enemies (flies), probably due to using the Flash engine. This is highly noticeable while playing the game, especially upon completing two certain bosses. It took me at least 10 in-game hours to get used to the wild framerate. Another issue is that the game may almost crash when it tries generating certain floors, which can be resolved by waiting for the program to respond even if the option to close the problem comes up.

If you are interested in trying out the game, it is fairly cheap normally ($4.99 + $2.99 DLC ( $6.60 bundle)). If you wait for it as a specific Steam Sale, the combined cost is aroudn $0.68, which is definitely worth the purchase.

That said, if you are interested in the game and would probably play this game a lot (tens and tens of hours), I would recommend purchasing The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, which is a remake of the original game and DLC. A lot of new items, challenges, characters, enemies, and bosses are introduced. The art style is better (imo), the mechanics are better due to the change in game engine, and the game runs much more smoothly. The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth costs $14.99 normally. It is up to you on which you purchase if you want to.

reviewText: The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike indie game devloped by Edmund McMillen, which I have owned for a few years. It presents a unique stoyline, focusing around Isaac, a small boy who it is presumed wishes for his mother's affection. As the game has a heavy religion focus, a god speaks to his mother with the order to end Isaac's life. Isaac, fearful of his mother finds a hidden trapdoor in his room, and delves into the depths of what is under the house. The game itself is mainly skill based, but partially luck based. Certain combinations of items can ensure an easy and victorious playthrough while other item comboes make a challenging and tedious one.  It contains endless tilesets aswell as a total of 11 different settings along with 7 characters. This game is insanely fun, and provides a testament to your dodging skills. There are many more positive things I can say about this game, but I advise you pick it up and find out yourself ;)

reviewText: Twisted comedy, endless replayability and hundrads of upgrades make the Binding of Issac one of my most played games. Due to its random nature no two runs are the same and while I cant say the Asthetic is for everyone, if you are even slightly interested i would strongly suggest you give it a whirl.

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac.

Oh dear Lord, The Binding of Isaac.

Hell. Yeah.

This has got to be one of the sickest, most disgusting, horrifying, frustrating yet amazingly addicting games I have ever played. Once I found myself in the Basement, I found I couldn't escape, in more ways than one.

This game is HARD. Like, balls-to-the-walls hard. Hell, it took me a few attempts just to get to the second floor. And then it took me more attempts to get two more floors or so. And so on and so forth. The game is frustrating to the point not of breaking you, but making you want to keep going. You'll die, and I'll think GAH! I ALMOST had it! ...Just ONE more try
recommended: just trying again isn't a guarantee of further progession or victory. The floors you play in are randomly generated each time you start a game
hoursPlayed: so the experience will never be exactly the same twice. That's part of the fun of this game - just seeing what's in store for you every time you give it another go.\n\nIn these randomly generated floors I've been randomly rambling about

helpfulPercent: items to help or hurt you
votesHelpful: shops
votesTotal: secret rooms found by blowing up walls

reviewText:
Surprisingly fun, extremely satisfying, and utterly brilliant.

The Binding of Issac is a mind-bogglingly simple, yet amazing game. Every dungeon is different, and so are the bosses.
The game is never the same twice, and even if it way, i would still play it.
Easy, fluid controls make glacking even the most stubborn fruitflies easy. A wonderful treasure room system changes the face of your character as well as your gaming experiance. I got a wire coathanger and eneded up having it shoved through my head!

A fun, refreshingly unique game i'd recommend to anyone!

reviewText:
If you like rogue-likes, this is about as good as you can get.

Pros:
Unique
Incredibly dark and creepy (so much that it might turn some people away; I liked it.)
Easy Game Mechanics
Item variation leads to different runs every time.

Cons:
The Random Number Generation is the embodiment of Satan.
No Multi-Player/Co-op (Although this is rumored to be in the sequel)
It doesn't cook me a delicious breakfast omelet.

If you like rogue-likes, buy this game.  Don't ask questions.  Just buy it.

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is one of those games that grows on you. The first time I played Isaac I remember being frustrated and felt that I wasted two dollars. I never bothered to play beyond the basement. It's difficult for me to pinpoint what initially put me off from Isaac, but I chalk up my ignorance to an inability to progress. I didn't enjoy losing and quickly concluded the game was simply not for me.

A couple years later one I was introduced to a livestreamer named LethalFrag. He often loaded up Binding of Isaac; one of his favorite games. While playing he often spoke highly of Isaac's replayability, soundtrack, and addictive gameplay. His praise helped me realize that Isaac deserved another look; and now I couldn't agree more with his assessment.

To appreciate The Binding of Isaac I needed to make some progress and unlock items. Dying stopped being so horrible as I faced each challenge and overcame them step by step. I understood that it was perfectly acceptable to lose; that's just part of the process. The trick was to pick myself up and learn from my mistakes. From there I was able to immerse myself in the gameplay.

I've now logged over one hundred hours into the original Binding of Isaac and Wrath of the Lamb. I still find myself coming back for more. With the release of Rebirth I play the original far less often, but the newest Eternals" update has got me back for what I expect will be another 100+ hours.

TL;DR: The Binding of Isaac is unquestionably the best investment I've ever made on Steam. There's still plenty to appreciate
date: though Rebirth is now a much smoother experience."

reviewText:
NOTE: Please buy the 'Wrath of the Lamb' DLC if you're going to get this. It will make TBoI a million times better, and will allow you to update the game to get the Hard Mode.

With randomly generated dungeons for every playthrough and a top down dungeon crawling experience in the same vein of the original Zelda trilogy, The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike game that can be picked up for less than a dollar and provides hours and hours of fun on end.

Following Isaac, a young boy who is trying to defeat his murderous mother after almost getting killed by her, TBoI has hundreds of items, ranging from the cutest of fashion accessories to the most grotesque parasites and diseases. With a randomisation system that makes no two playthroughs the same, TBoI is an adventure, a big step forward in the world of indie gaming, and ultimately, you'll have a hell of a time playing it.

My criticisms with the game are that it's impossible to predict what items you're going to get, and while this adds to the mystery, this also means you can become obscenely OP or obscenely UP and it can become frustrating having to play through with what could be called a dead weight on your leg, which combined with the VERY steep learning curve, makes for a frustrating time with some playthroughs.

Nonetheless, with a game that you can pick up for less than one dollar, where can you go wrong? I highly reccommend TBoI, and if you like it, go pick up the remake, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth!

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a frustratingly-fun and challenging zelda-style rogue-lite, created by Edmund McMillen (Super Meat Boy) and Florian Himsl (Coil, The C-Word).

The game features a ton of variables in the forms of characters, bosses, items, and power-ups, all of which can alter how much you progress throughout the game.

With hilarious (and sometimes creepy) references to faith, religion, human ethics, and biology, Isaac is a delicious slice of blasphemy, served with a sour lemon.

reviewText: The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike indie game devloped by Edmund McMillen, which I have owned for a few years. It presents a unique stoyline, focusing around Isaac, a small boy who it is presumed wishes for his mother's affection. As the game has a heavy religion focus, a god speaks to his mother with the order to end Isaac's life. Isaac, fearful of his mother finds a hidden trapdoor in his room, and delves into the depths of what is under the house. The game itself is mainly skill based, but partially luck based. Certain combinations of items can ensure an easy and victorious playthrough while other item comboes make a challenging and tedious one.  It contains endless tilesets aswell as a total of 11 different settings along with 7 characters. This game is insanely fun, and provides a testament to your dodging skills. There are many more positive things I can say about this game, but I advise you pick it up and find out yourself ;)

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a Difficult, dark, action indie game that is a lot of fun. It sort of reminds me of Out There Somewhere and Realm of the Mad God.

The Binding of Isaac is a dark game. And I mean DARK. The story your led to believe is that Isaac's mother was told by God himself that Isaac was corrupted, and needed to be killed. This sacrifice would prove Isaac's mother's loyalty to him. But, before she gets the chance, Isaac escapes to the basement. The game is very simple: WASD to move, arrow keys to fire your tears, and E or Left Shift to place bombs. That's about all of the controls. The game is completely random, so no two playthroughs will be the same. Also, if you die, you have to restart the ENTIRE game over. So, my advice, just stay alive, and don't die.

Overall, this is a very fun, and unique, and dark game. If you NOT like dark games, then you will not like this. Otherwise, I recommend this game to everyone. Also, if you are a Christian, then you may not like this game. No offense

reviewText:
Story: A bit dark and filled with jabs at religion. That doesn't bother me, but the game is definitly not appropriate for a younger audience and those who don't take religion jokes lightly.  Also, some of the bosses/mobs are a bit gruesome and distrubing (but I dont mind!!).

The game without the DLC has about 7 levels, takes me about an hour (on a good run) to beat the game. Considering that I have more than 20 hours into this game and have only beaten it 5 times :C. The trick to this game is that death is permanent for your current playthrough. Once you die you have to restart at the beginning and pray for good items.

IF you aren't accustomed to the perma-death scenario I don't reccommend this game. I enjoy it purely because of the flexibility of the levels and the ever-changing drops.

This game is a great game and has a good price imo.

reviewText:
tldr:
6/10 - A rather mediocre top-down rogue action game with dark humor. I keep returning to it when I have a minute and I don't feel like doing anything complex or time consuming. Would absolutely skip if it wasn't on sale. Still very recommended at a reasonable price if you're looking for a simple casual game which is easy to get into.


too long part:
STORY - ?/10
You're playing as Isaac - a little kid whose mom is nuts and wants to kill him, so he descends through a trap door in his room to fight his way through creepy places with creepy monsters in them.


GAMEPLAY - 6/10
- Simple but hard to master controls. Depends on anyones taste.

- The game has its own economy and a SH*TLOAD of upgrades, active skills and consumables to be discovered. Each upgrade and skill is very interesting and fun to mess around with. While it's tempting to google what does what, it's way better fun to just pick something up and see what it does.

- Levels are randomized and there is a lot of various monsters and bosses to spice things up. You won't play the game the same way twice. From this point of view the game offers infinite replayability, but...

- The fact that everything is so heavily randomized prevents you from forming any sort of your own strategy. You just dive in and keep going until you win or die. Over time, this reduces the cool variety to the point where you're doing the same thing over and over again and it's only a liiiiiiiittle bit different because of some dice roll.

- There is not much persistence to keep you returning for more. There are few unlockable characters and mandatory achievements but upgrades and skills are limited for each run where you find them. While it's nice to know that the game doesn't have you on a leash trying to unlock everything, it doesn't really motivate you to achieve anything when you start from zero every single time.

reviewText: The binding of Isaac is a brilliant little procedurally generated dungeon crawler in which you must make it through each level of your toy box in order to defeat your mother. This game recquires huge levels of concentration and multi-tasking as you'll be ducking around to avoid flies and enemy tears. This game however is not as innocent as it looks though as if you fail or make the slightest mistake it may come back to bite you later when you need just the tinniest part of health. Anyway this game is an amazing sign of just what a small group of people can achieve and you can see to this day that edmund mcmillin has created many of amazing games. This game is perfect for when your kicking back and want just a small dose of this game or want to play hardcore. This is brilliant, I'm giving it a 7.5/10

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac.

Oh dear Lord, The Binding of Isaac.

Hell. Yeah.

This has got to be one of the sickest, most disgusting, horrifying, frustrating yet amazingly addicting games I have ever played. Once I found myself in the Basement, I found I couldn't escape, in more ways than one.

This game is HARD. Like, balls-to-the-walls hard. Hell, it took me a few attempts just to get to the second floor. And then it took me more attempts to get two more floors or so. And so on and so forth. The game is frustrating to the point not of breaking you, but making you want to keep going. You'll die, and I'll think GAH! I ALMOST had it! ...Just ONE more try
recommended: just trying again isn't a guarantee of further progession or victory. The floors you play in are randomly generated each time you start a game
hoursPlayed: so the experience will never be exactly the same twice. That's part of the fun of this game - just seeing what's in store for you every time you give it another go.\n\nIn these randomly generated floors I've been randomly rambling about

reviewText:
This might be my favorite game of 2011.
Endlessly replayable, devilishly hard, and so so fun when you get to break it over your knee.
On the downside, the engine is kind of buggy because it's made in flash. That's really the only complaint I have. If memes get you angry this is probably not the game for you, but if they actually make you angry you have bigger problems than videogames.
Highly recommend, there's a reason it's eaten up 2 entire weeks of my life.

reviewText: Twisted comedy, endless replayability and hundrads of upgrades make the Binding of Issac one of my most played games. It is a dark twisted roguelike mixed with a layout lifted from the original zelda leading to simple controlls and easy to learn concepts with an ochean of underlieing complexity. Due to its random nature no two runs are the same and while I cant say the Asthetic is for everyone, if you are even slightly interested i would strongly suggest you give it a whirl.

reviewText:
First of all, I am shocked at this game; from a religious standpoint I'd have to say it is utterly perfect for my fellow Christian players to enjoy; 10/10, recommend it, God Bless You.

This addictive randomly generated dungeon crawler is absolutely stunning, though it is very simple and lacking in depth (I'd like some more bosses and items, maybe my wish will be granted in Rebirth) it continues to entertain for hours and hours. Every time I thought I will play one game more and was stuck for another 20 hours. If you compare the cost and the time played; this is definitely worth it and a fun game to play if you're watching a film on the other side of your screen, so simple yet so much fun!

I would say more about the references, humour and plot but I'll just let you find that out for yourself, the game is barely a fiver, just get it already.

reviewText: 64 hours of nightmare... I think I'm lucky to beat this game to 100% in 64 hours. I don't even know, should I recommend this game? I think I should. The Binding of Isaac, an amazing roguelike game. The game's mechanics and presentation is similar to the dungeons of The Legend of Zelda, while incorporating random, procedurally-generated levels. Every room you enter, you must clear it if you wanna get outta there or put a bomb in front of the door that will do it too. Each floor of the dungeon includes a boss which you must defeat before continuing to the next level. Oh yeah, they have item rooms too. You can unlock new characters if you can get some achievements. This game has a lotta religious refences, oh wait, not only refences this games is about the Christianity. We can say that I suppose. So, this is the best roguelike, dungeon crawler game I've ever played. I can't wait for The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth. I'm ready for it! Buy this game and prepare yourself for Rebirth! Oh I almost forgot, this is a flash game so you know what it means. Whatever, just buy it!

reviewText: One of the best Indie Games I've ever played.

reviewText:
After playing Super meat boy, I started looking out for new games by the same developer. Edmund Mcmillenâ€™s wonderfully strange imagination is an interesting thing to explore through his games, thatâ€™s for sure.

This game was not a disappointment. At first, I had no idea what to expect, the trailer was very strange but a tad intriguing. When I came across it there was next to no information about the game and the mechanics of it on the store page and back then there was no costumer reviews to go off of. Admittedly I never actually brought it to give it a go off of the information I was given, I ended up with it from a bundle and itâ€™s the only reason I really played it. Although I wish I had taken the leap to try it because it is well worth it.

Binding of Isaac is a randomly generated dungeon crawler, one I have heard to be described as Zelda-like youâ€™re a young boy running from his demented mother. Who has been blinded by her hard-core Christianity and believes that the voice of god has spoken to her and told her to murder her son to prove her loyalty. So a very interesting concept, indeed.

A short cut scene plays on start-up, which expands on what I just described, you find yourself wandering through randomly generated dungeon floors, fighting monsters, picking up loot and items as you go along that changes how you fight, gives you different abilities and drastically changes Isaacâ€™s image. At the end of each floor, you fight a boss, and move on down to the next floor. It being harder than before, with a bigger space to explore and more enemies to defeat.

Thereâ€™s a large range of items to collect that when found for the first time is added to the â€œthings I foundâ€ section in the main menu, so a lovely bit of collecting there to entice those OCD minded like myself, Thereâ€™s new characters to unlock which vary in stats, challenges to complete and even some DLC that can extend your gameplay.

You are given one life and one life only. You can find hearts to heal, but once you are dead, thatâ€™s it, you start all over again. So throughout the whole game and especially when nearing the end, it starts to put a little pressure on and gets that heart rate going. Iâ€™m not one to be good under pressure so it gets me every time. I FINALLY managed to complete the game a few times over, again, admittedly, only after I gained some â€œtop tipsâ€ from my way-to-good-at-games brother. There have been people that have completed the game 10 times over and still not gotten bored. I think that the randomly generated dungeon element to it keeps its replay ability intact. If it were to replay the same levels over and over when you died, the game would be a lot different and no doubt a lot less popular.

I have heard from friends that it is quite hard to complete without â€œdoing your researchâ€ on the wiki or seeking tips from those nerdy minded like my brother who managed to figure all of it out themselves. I on the other hand find that kind of thing enjoyable, because it beats you every time and you work and research and try to understand the game more to finally get to that ending. I can quite honestly say that the first time I reached the end, my heart has never beaten that loud or that fast in a long time. And that sense of accomplishment you get from finishing a game, is a on a much higher scale when you work to complete this one.

The music is great, it fits the setting perfectly and is great to listen to. Rarely have I actually wanted to download a gameâ€™s soundtrack, I can give most soundtracks a thumbs up but not often do I actually want to listen to game music outside of gaming.
The art, as per usual in Edmunds games, is amazing. And I hear they are also looking to remake the game to have a more â€œretroâ€ look, with possible multiplayer features. Which should be very interesting. For those interested you can look up â€œBinding of Isaac: Rebirthâ€.

All in all, it is a great indie game, which is both fun and challenging. Definitely worth trying, I am not usually the dungeon crawler type, but this game is a lot of fun. The only fault that I had with this game, which has bothered me quite a few times now, is that I have lost my save for no reason. The game is listed as having â€˜Steam Cloudâ€™ features, but it definitely doesn't work. I haven't uninstalled the game, I haven't touched it. But recently I hopped on and seen all the progress that I had made was gone. And for a game that has no real save points or ongoing plot to keep up with, your stats, unlocked characters and collection of things you have found is pretty much all you have. I was pretty upset to see it had vanished and itâ€™s something I felt I needed to warn people about.


TL;DR : Awesome music, fun and engaging game with a slightly 'twisted' side to it. It's a challenge to reach the end and you can definitely end up putting a lot of hours into this. Addictive and awesome all around.

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac is a Difficult, dark, action indie game that is a lot of fun. It sort of reminds me of Out There Somewhere and Realm of the Mad God.

The Binding of Isaac is a dark game. And I mean DARK. The story your led to believe is that Isaac's mother was told by God himself that Isaac was corrupted, and needed to be killed. This sacrifice would prove Isaac's mother's loyalty to him. But, before she gets the chance, Isaac escapes to the basement. The game is very simple: WASD to move, arrow keys to fire your tears, and E or Left Shift to place bombs. That's about all of the controls. The game is completely random, so no two playthroughs will be the same. Also, if you die, you have to restart the ENTIRE game over. So, my advice, just stay alive, and don't die.

Overall, this is a very fun, and unique, and dark game. If you NOT like dark games, then you will not like this. Otherwise, I recommend this game to everyone. Also, if you are a Christian, then you may not like this game. No offense

reviewText:
After 28.3 hours, i want to review The Binding Of Isaac
Story:
This is The Binding Of Isaac, where you play as boy who his name is Isaac and  he lives with his religiously Mother.
One day his Mother received an order from God to kill Isaac where you gonna see it at the opening of the game. When his mother received the order from God, Isaac was locked out in his room, and Isaac sees her already preparing knife to kill Isaac. His mother kicked the Isaac door room. Isaac dont know what to do and underneath his carpet theres like a cave full of evil things where Isaac gonna escape from his mother, this is where the adventure starts.

Gameplay:
At first when i play, suddenly i get used to it (yeah because it was easy..). Im so addicted to this gane, even if im always losing, i just want to finish it again and again. After you defeat the boss, you get into the different cave and gonna defeat all the boss again, until you reach the main boss fight. To makes thing easy this game gives you like ability, unique items and power-ups! And make your own Isaac looks weird AF. Well i dont know what to say anymore, its just very good and addicting!

Dont hesitate if you're buying this game or not, just buy it people! And its actually cheap for me especially when this game on sale, i got this when there's Hallowen Sale last year. It is worth it...

reviewText:
Autism is a disorder of neural development characterized by impaired social interaction and verbal and non-verbal communication, and by restricted, repetitive or stereotyped behavior. The diagnostic criteria require that symptoms become apparent before a child is three years old.[2] Autism affects information processing in the brain by altering how nerve cells and their synapses connect and organize; how this occurs is not well understood.[3] It is one of three recognized disorders in the autism spectrum (ASDs), the other two being Asperger syndrome, which lacks delays in cognitive development and language, and pervasive developmental disorder, not otherwise specified (commonly abbreviated as PDD-NOS), which is diagnosed when the full set of criteria for autism or Asperger syndrome are not met.[4]

Autism has a strong genetic basis, although the genetics of autism are complex and it is unclear whether ASD is explained more by rare mutations, or by rare combinations of common genetic variants.[5] In rare cases, autism is strongly associated with agents that cause birth defects.[6] Controversies surround other proposed environmental causes, such as heavy metals, pesticides or childhood vaccines;[7] the vaccine hypotheses are biologically implausible and lack convincing scientific evidence.[8] The prevalence of autism is about 1â€“2 per 1,000 people worldwide, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) report 20 per 1,000 children in the United States are diagnosed with ASD as of 2012 (up from 11 per 1,000 in 2008).[7][9][10] The number of people diagnosed with autism has been increasing dramatically since the 1980s, partly due to changes in diagnostic practice and government-subsidized financial incentives for named diagnoses;[10] the question of whether actual prevalence has increased is unresolved.[11]

Parents usually notice signs in the first two years of their child's life.[12] The signs usually develop gradually, but some autistic children first develop more normally and then regress.[13] Early behavioral, cognitive, or speech interventions can help autistic children gain self-care, social, and communication skills.[12] Although there is no known cure,[12] there have been reported cases of children who recovered.[14] Not many children with autism live independently after reaching adulthood, though some become successful.[15] An autistic culture has developed, with some individuals seeking a cure and others believing autism should be accepted as a difference and not treated as a disorder.[16]
